rsbNotes.title: Ps 33
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 33 There are twenty-two verses in the psalm, the same as the number of letters in the Hebrew alphabet, but the psalm is not an acrostic (see Introduction to Hebrew Poetry).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:3
rsbNotes.text: 33:3 new song. Often such “new” psalms are found in contexts of victorious war and can be seen as shouts of victory. Cf. Ps. 96; 98; 144; 149; Is. 42:10; Rev. 5:9; 14:3).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:4
rsbNotes.text: 33:4 the word of the Lord is upright. God’s speech to men reflects His character. He does not deceive His people, but leads them into the truth. The Bible, as God’s written Word, does the same.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:6
rsbNotes.text: 33:6 all their host. Literally, this word is simply “hosts” and may refer not merely to the innumerable stars of heaven, but also to the angelic armies.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:7
rsbNotes.text: 33:7 the waters of the sea. The creator is pictured poetically as exercising command over the waters of chaos (Ps. 18:16 note). There may also be a poetical allusion to the song of Moses and Israel at the Red Sea (Ex. 15).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:8
rsbNotes.text: 33:8 fear the Lord. To honor, love, and obey Him.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:10
rsbNotes.text: 33:10 nations. Godless nations who seek their own will and not God’s.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:11
rsbNotes.text: 33:11 The counsel of the Lord stands forever. Nothing can subvert God’s purposes. He is in absolute control of history.
